revision.text:
The '''Acadian World Congress''', or '''Le Congrès Mondial Acadien''', is a festival of [[Acadian]] and [[Cajun]] culture and history, held every five years. It is also informally known as the ''Acadian Reunion''. Its creator was André Boudreau (1945-2005).<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/new-brunswick/story/2005/11/24/nb-boudreau-obit-20051124.html]</ref>
==History== The first congress was held in [[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]] in 1994, and the second was held in south Louisiana from July 31 to August 15, 1999. The 1999 event featured the reunions of over 80 Acadian families, three major concerts (Houma, Oak Alley Plantation, and Lafayette Cajundome), and academic conferences centered on economics, culture, women's issues, genealogy and genetics. The President and executive director of the 1999 event was Brian Gabriel Comeaux of Lafayette, LA.
===2004 World Congress=== The third congress, in 2004, was held jointly by several [[Nova Scotia]] communities in the ancestral [[Acadia|Acadie]] region, and celebrated the 400th anniversary of the arrival of the first French-speaking settlers in Canada. As in the previous gatherings, musical festivals and theatrical productions displayed Acadian culture, and academics debated the meaning of Acadia in the 21st century. Debate topics included the best ways of preserving Acadian culture in an overwhelmingly English area, and what exactly an Acadian is in 2004. Some Acadians in the [[Maritimes]] do not recognize more recent immigrants as true Acadians. There was also a debate about whether the descendants of Acadians, who do not speak French, qualify (see [[Chiac language]]).
===2009 World Congress=== The 2009 Acadian World Congress was held in the [[Acadian Peninsula]].
===2014 World Congress=== The 2014 Acadian World Congress was held along the [[Canada–United States border]], co-hosted by [[Maine]]'s [[Aroostook County, Maine|Aroostook County]] in the [[United States]] and its neighbouring counties in [[Canada]] ([[Témiscouata Regional County Municipality|Témiscouata]] in Quebec, and [[Victoria County, New Brunswick|Victoria]], [[Madawaska County, New Brunswick|Madawaska]] and [[Restigouche County, New Brunswick|Restigouche]] in New Brunswick).<ref>{{cite news|last=Olmstead|first=Kathryn|title=Van Buren, Canadian towns reach across border to get ready for World Acadian Congress in August|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/04/10/living/van-buren-canadian-towns-reach-across-border-to-get-ready-for-world-acadian-congress-in-august/|accessdate=11 April 2014|newspaper=[[Bangor Daily News]]|date=10 April 2014|archiveurl=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/04/10/living/van-buren-canadian-towns-reach-across-border-to-get-ready-for-world-acadian-congress-in-august/|archivedate=11 April 2014}}</ref><ref>http://bangordailynews.com/2015/01/20/news/aroostook/world-acadian-congress-final-numbers-half-of-what-had-been-forecast/</ref>
===2019 World Congress===
The 2019 Congress is planned to be held on [[Prince Edward Island]] and in [[New Brunswick]], with its central events being held in [[Summerside, Prince Edward Island|Summerside]]. <ref>{{cite news|last=McKay|first=Millicent|title=Congrès Mondial Acadien less than a year away, to be held in eight Island communities|url=http://www.journalpioneer.com/news/local/congres-mondial-acadien-less-than-a-year-away-to-be-held-in-eight-island-communities-233517/|accessdate=17 August 2018|newspaper=[[Journal Pioneer]]|date=13 August 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091223213800/http://www.cma2014.com/ 2014 Acadian World Congress]
{{Acadia}}

{{about|methods of preparation of a drink|the species of coffee plant|Coffea arabica}} {{Infobox food | name = Arabic coffee | image = [[Image:A dallah a traditional Arabic coffee pot with cups and coffee beans.jpg||260px]] | caption = A [[Dallah (coffee pot)|dallah]] is a traditional Arabic coffee pot with cups and coffee beans | alternate_name = Qahwah arabiyya | country = [[ Arabia ]] | region = [[Middle East]] | national_cuisine = [[Middle Eastern cuisine]] | year = 15th century | mintime = | maxtime = | type = [[Coffea arabica]] | course = [[Drink]] | served = [[List of hot drinks|Hot]] | main_ingredient = | minor_ingredient = | variations = | serving_size = 100 g | calories = | protein = | fat = | carbohydrate = | glycemic_index = | other = }} '''Arabic coffee''' ({{lang-ar|قهوة عربية|qahwah arabiyya||link=}}, {{IPA-ar|ˈqah.wa ʕaraˈbijːah|-|Arabic coffee ar.ogg}}) refers to a version of the brewed coffee of ''[[Coffea arabica]]'' beans. Arabic coffee is typically grown at a height of 1000 to 2000 meters, and represents about 60-70% of the coffee industry in the world{{cite web|title=Botanical Aspects |publisher=International Coffee Organization |location=London |url=http://www.ico.org/botanical.asp |accessdate=4 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324155957/http://www.ico.org/botanical.asp |archivedate=24 March 2009 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|title=1.2.5-World coffee trade-World production by type: arabica and robusta|url=http://www.intracen.org/coffee-guide/world-coffee-trade/world-production-by-type-arabica-and-robusta/|website=www.intracen.org}}. Most [[Arab world|Arab countries]] throughout the [[Middle East]] have developed unique methods for brewing and preparing coffee. [[Cardamom]] is an often-added spice,{{cite web|title=Ingredients Arabic Coffee|url=http://www.nestle-family.com/nescafe/arabiana/nescafe-arabiana-product.aspx}} but it can alternatively be served plain ({{lang-ar|قهوة سادة|qahwah sādah|lit=plain coffee|link=no}}). There are mainly two types of Arabic coffee; one with a golden colour made mainly in [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|the Gulf region]], and the other is black. There are several different styles to brewing the coffee depending on the preference of the drinker. Some methods keep the coffee light, which usually contains cardamom, whereas others can make it dark. Arabic coffee is [[Taste|bitter]], and typically no sugar is added. It is usually served in a small cup that is adorned with a decorative pattern, known as a finjān. Culturally, Arabic coffee is served during family gatherings or when receiving guests. Arabic coffee is ingrained within Middle Eastern and Arab culture and tradition, and is the most popular form of coffee brewed in the Middle East. It originated in the [[Middle East]], beginning in [[Yemen]] and eventually travelling to [[Mecca]] ([[Hejaz]]), [[Egypt]], the [[Levant]], and then, in the mid-16th century, to [[Turkey]]. Arabic coffee is an [[Intangible cultural heritage|Intangible Cultural Heritage]] of [[Arab states]] confirmed by [[UNESCO]].{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/en/RL/arabic-coffee-a-symbol-of-generosity-01074|title=Arabic coffee, a symbol of generosity - intangible heritage - Culture Sector - UNESCO|website=www.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-04}} == Etymology == [[File:John Frederick Lewis 004.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Arab women]] (coffee bearer) by [[John Frederick Lewis]] (1857). in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]])]] The word "coffee" entered the English language in 1582 via the Dutch ''koffie'',''[[OED]]'', ''s.v.'' "Coffee". borrowed from the [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] ''kahve'', in turn borrowed from the [[Arabic]] [[wiktionary:قهوة|قَهْوَة]] (qahwa, “coffee, a brew”).''Oxford English Dictionary'', 1st ed. "coffee, ''n.''" Oxford University Press (Oxford), 1891. The word ''qahwah'' may have originally referred to the drink's reputation as an appetite suppressant from the word ''qahiya'' ({{lang-ar|قَهِيَ|qahiya|lit=to lack hunger}}).{{cite journal|last=Kaye|first=Alan|date=1986|title=The Etymology of Coffee: The Dark Brew|journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society|volume=106|issue=3|page=557|doi=10.2307/602112|jstor=602112}}{{cite web|script-title=قهي |url=http://www.baheth.info/all.jsp?term=%D9%82%D9%87%D9%8A|work=الباحث العربي |accessdate=September 25, 2011|language=ar}}(see also [http://www.ejtaal.net/aa/#hw4=943,ll=2665,ls=16,la=3767,sg=880,ha=644,br=804,pr=130,aan=541,mgf=739,vi=311,kz=2231,mr=568,mn=1168,uqw=1367,umr=905,ums=767,umj=690,ulq=1452,uqa=359,uqq=319,bdw=h739,amr=h534,asb=h825,auh=h1333,dhq=h469,mht=h766,msb=h205,tla=h88,amj=h681,ens=h1,mis=h1 qahiya: Hans Wehr's ''Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic'']. page 930.) The name ''qahwah'' is not used for the berry or plant (the products of the region), which are known in Arabic as ''bunn''. Semitic had a root ''qhh'' "dark color", which became a natural designation for the beverage. According to this analysis, the feminine form ''qahwah'' (also meaning "dark in color, dull(ing), dry, sour") also had the meaning of wine, which was also often dark in color.{{cite journal |first=Alan S. |last=Kaye |title=The etymology of "coffee": The dark brew |journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society |volume=106 |number=3 |pages=557–558 |year=1986 |doi=10.2307/602112 |jstor=602112}} == History == The earliest credible evidence of either coffee drinking or knowledge of the coffee tree appears in the middle of the 15th century, in [[Yemen]]'s [[Sufi]] monasteries.{{cite book|first1=Bennett Alan|last1=Weinberg|first2=Bonnie K.|last2=Bealer|title=The world of caffeine|year=2001|pages=3–4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qyz5CnOaH9oC&pg=PA3&dq=coffee+goat+ethiopia+Kaldi&lr=&ei=paxHStuDJ4XuzATj97hf | isbn=978-0-415-92723-9 | publisher=Routledge}} Sufis used it to keep themselves alert during their nighttime devotions. A translation of Al-Jaziri's manuscriptAl-Jaziri's manuscript work is of considerable interest with regards to the history of coffee in Europe as well. A copy reached the French royal library, where it was translated in part by [[Antoine Galland]] as ''De l'origine et du progrès du café''. traces the spread of coffee from ''Arabia Felix'' (the present day Yemen) northward to [[Mecca]] and [[Medina]], and then to the larger cities of [[Cairo]], [[Damascus]], [[Baghdad]], and [[Constantinople]]. In 1511, it was forbidden for its stimulating effect by conservative, orthodox imams at a theological court in [[Mecca]].{{cite web|title=resource for arabic books|url=http://www.alwaraq.net/Core/waraq/bibliography_indetail?id=184|website=www.alwaraq.net}} However, these bans were to be overturned in 1524 by an order of the [[Ottoman Dynasty|Ottoman Turkish]] [[Sultan]] [[Suleiman the Magnificent|Suleiman I]], with [[Grand Mufti]] [[Mehmet Ebussuud el-İmadi]] issuing a ''[[fatwa]]'' allowing the consumption of coffee.{{cite book | last= Schneider | first= Irene | chapter= Ebussuud |editor= Michael Stolleis |title= Juristen: ein biographisches Lexikon; von der Antike bis zum 20. Jahrhundert |edition= 2nd |year= 2001 |publisher= Beck |location= München |language= German |isbn= 3-406-45957-9 |page= 193}} In [[Cairo]], Egypt, a similar ban was instituted in 1532, and the coffeehouses and warehouses containing coffee beans were sacked.{{cite book |author=J. E. Hanauer | title= Folk-lore of the Holy Land | year= 1907 |chapter=About Coffee | quote=[All] the coffee-houses [were] closed, and their keepers pelted with the sherds of their pots and cups. This was in 1524, but by an order of Selìm I., the decrees of the learned were reversed, the disturbances in Egypt quieted, the drinking of coffee declared perfectly orthodox |at=pp. 291 f.}} == Preparation == [[Image:Dallahs.png|thumb|220px|[[Dallah (coffee pot)|Dallahs]]]] Arabic coffee is made from coffee beans roasted very lightly or heavily from {{convert|165|to|210|C|F}} and cardamom, and is a traditional beverage in Arab culture.{{Cite news|url=http://www.yourmiddleeast.com/features/what-makes-arabic-coffee-unique_9351|title=What makes Arabic coffee unique?|work=Your Middle East|access-date=2017-04-14|language=sv}} Traditionally, it is roasted on the premises (at home or for special occasions), ground, brewed and served in front of guests. It is often served with dates, dried fruit, candied fruit or nuts.{{cite web|url=http://www.dlc.fi/~marianna/gourmet/19_30.htm|title=Gulf Arabic coffee - qahwa arabiyyah|website=www.dlc.fi|access-date=2017-04-14}} Arabic coffee, is defined by the method of preparation and flavors, rather than the type or roast beans. Arabic coffee is boiled coffee that is not filtered, made black. Sugar is not typically added, but if so, it can be added during preparation or when serving. It is served in a small delicate cup without handles, called finjān. Sometimes, the coffee is moved to a larger and more beautiful pour pitcher to serve in front of the guests, called Della. Often, though, the host prepares coffee in the kitchen and highlights a tray of small cups of coffee.{{Cite news|url=http://www.terracerestaurantandlounge.com/how-to-make-arabic-coffee-7-steps/|title=How To Make Arabic Coffee|date=2015-03-01|work=Terrace Restaurant & Lounge|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}} Unlike its [[Turkish coffee|Turkish]] counterparts, traditional Arabic coffee, with its roots in [[Bedouin]] tradition, is usually unsweetened (qahwah saada), but sugar can added depending on the preference of drinker. However, this coffee is never sweet syrup, but rather strong and bitter. To make up for the bitter flavor, coffee is usually served with something sweet{{snd}}dates are a traditional accompaniment{{snd}}and other desserts are often served along with a tray of coffee cups.
"''Coffee should be black as hell, strong as death, and sweet as love.''" - Turkish Proverb{{Cite web|url=http://food-heritage.org/wordpress/lebanese-coffee/|title=Food Heritage Foundation – Lebanese coffee|website=food-heritage.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-20}}
[[Image:Coffee Souq Waqif Doha.jpg|thumb|left|widthpx|Kanaka also called rikwah or jezwah at [[Souq Waqif]] in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].]] === Arabian Peninsula === Arabs in the Gulf are also creative in the way they prepare coffee. Coffee is different from that in Egypt and [[Levant]] in terms of bitterness and the type of cups the coffee is served in. This brewing method is common in [[Najd]] and [[Hejaz]], and sometimes other [[spice]]s like [[saffron]] (to give it a golden color), [[cloves]], and [[cinnamon]]. Some people add a little-[[evaporated milk]] to slightly alter its color; however, this is rare. It is prepared in and served from a special coffee pot called [[Dallah (coffee pot)|dallah]] ({{lang-ar|'''دلة'''}}); more commonly used is the coffee pot called [[cezve]] (also called rikwah or kanaka) and the coffee cups are small with no handle called ''fenjan''. The portions are small, covering just the bottom of the cup. It is served in homes, and in good restaurants by specially clad waiters called ''gahwaji'', and it is almost always accompanied with dates. It is always offered with the compliments of the house.[[Image:Different_Types_of_Arabic_Coffee.jpg|thumb|367x367px|The different types of Arabic coffee with the [[Hejazi]] / [[Najd]]i golden coffee seen on the left and the [[Levant]]ine black "qahwah sādah" (plain coffee) on the right.]] === Levant === The hot beverage that [[Palestinians]] consume is coffee{{snd}}served in the morning and throughout the day. The coffee of choice is usually Arabic coffee. Arabic coffee is similar to Turkish coffee, but the former is spiced with [[cardamom]] and is usually unsweetened.[http://imeu.net/news/article001840.shtml The rich flavors of Palestine] Farsakh, Mai M. Institute for Middle East Understanding (IMEU), (Originally published by [http://www.thisweekinpalestine.com/ This Week in Palestine]) 2006-06-21 Accessed on 2007-12-18 Among [[Bedouin]]s and most other [[Arab]]s throughout the region of Palestine, bitter coffee, known as ''qahwah sadah'' (Lit. plain coffee), was a symbol of [[hospitality]]. Pouring the drink was ceremonial; it would involve the host or his eldest son moving clockwise among guests{{snd}}who were judged by age and status{{snd}}pouring coffee into tiny cups from a brass pot. It was considered "polite" for guests to accept only three cups of coffee and then end their last cup by saying ''daymen'', meaning "always", but intending to mean "may you always have the means to serve coffee".[https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0931722934/ref=sib_dp_pt#reader-link A Taste of Palestine: Menus and Memories] (1993). [[Aziz Shihab]]. Corona Publishing Co. p.5 {{ISBN|978-0-931722-93-6}} [[File:Bedouincoffeecup.jpg|thumb|left|[[Arabs|Arab]] [[Bedouin]] from a beehive village in [[Aleppo]], [[State of Syria|Syria]], sipping the traditional murra (bitter) coffee, 1930]] In Lebanon, the coffee is prepared in a long-handled [[Coffeemaker|coffee pot]] called "rakwe". Coffee is poured directly from "rakwe" to a small cup that is adorned with a decorative pattern, known as a finjān. The finjān has a capacity of 60-90 ml (2-3 oz fl). Lebanese coffee is traditionally strong and black and is similar to the coffee of other Middle Eastern countries. However it differs in its beans and roast, where the blonde and dark beans are mixed together. It is also ground into a very particle like size.{{Cite web|url=http://maatouk.com/lebCoffee.aspx|title=Lebanese Coffee, Coffee passion|website=maatouk.com|access-date=2018-08-20}} It is often joked that a Lebanese person who does not drink coffee is in danger of losing their nationality. Drinks in [[Syria]] vary depending on the time of day and the occasion. Arabic coffee is the most well-known hot drink usually prepared in the morning at [[breakfast]] or in the evening. It is usually served for guests or after [[food]]. Arabic coffee is much more than just a drink in Jordan{{snd}}it is a traditional sign of respect and a way to bring people together. Black, cardamom-flavored Arabic coffee, also known as ''qahwah sādah'' (welcome coffee), deeply ingrained in [[Culture of Jordan|Jordanian culture]]. Providing coffee (and tea) to guests is a large part of the intimate hospitality of the [[Jordan|Hashemite Kingdom]]. === Morocco === Arabic coffee is the national drink of [[Morocco]], it is often made with the purpose of conducting a business deal, bargaining or welcoming someone into their home. == Cultivation == [[File:Jerusalem cafe du rue 1858.jpg|thumb|upright|A ''maqhah'' in [[Jerusalem]] during [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] rule in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], 1858]] Much of the popularization of coffee is due to its cultivation in the Arab world, beginning in what is now Yemen, by Sufi monks in the 15th century.{{Cite book|title=Cuisine and Culture: A History of Food and People|last=Civitello|first=Linda|publisher=John Wiley|year=2007|isbn=9780471741725|location=Hoboken, NJ|pages=|quote=|via=}} Through thousands of Arabs pilgrimaging to [[Mecca]], the enjoyment and harvesting of coffee, or the "wine of Araby" spread to other Arab countries (e.g. Egypt, [[Syria]]) and eventually to a majority of the world through the 16th century. Coffee, in addition to being essential in the home, became a major part of social life.{{Cite book|title=Alif Baa: Introduction to Arabic Letters and Sounds|last=Brustad|first=Kristen|last2=Al-Batal|first2=Mahmoud|last3=Al-Tonsi|first3=Abbas|publisher=Georgetown University Press|year=2010|isbn=9781589016330|location=|page=132|quote=|via=}} Coffeehouses, qahwa قَهوة in [[Modern Standard Arabic]], became "Schools of the Wise" as they developed into places of intellectual discussion, in addition to centers of relaxation and comradery.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncausa.org/About-Coffee/History-of-Coffee|title=The History Of Coffee|last=|first=|date=October 24, 2016|website=ncausa.org|publisher=National Coffee Association of the U.S.A.|access-date=}} == Coffeehouse == [[Image:1004-CoffeeSceneCairo18th.jpg|thumb|left|Coffeehouse in Cairo, 18th c.]] [[Coffeehouse]] culture began in the [[Arab world]], and eventually spread to other areas of the world and blended with the local culture.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/934667227|title=Coffee and Coffeehouses The Origins of a Social Beverage in the Medieval Near East.|last=S.,|first=Hattox, Ralph|date=2014-01-01|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=0295805498|oclc=934667227}} Traditional Arab coffeehouses are places where mostly men meet to socialize over games, coffee, and water pipes ([[Hookah|shisha]] or agriile). Depending on where the coffeehouse is, its specialty differs. In [[Maghreb]], green tea is served with mint or coffee is served Arab and/or European style. Arabic coffee, or Turkish coffee, is made in [[Egypt]] and the [[Levant|Levant countries]]. Arabic coffee is a very small amount of dark coffee boiled in a pot and presented in a demitasse cup. Particularly in Egypt, coffee is served mazbuuta, which means the amount of sugar will be "just right", about one teaspoon per cup. However, in the [[Arabian Peninsula]], Arabic coffee is roasted in such a way that the coffee is almost clear. In all of the Arab world, it is traditional for the host to refill the guest's cup until politely signaled that the guest is finished. == Served == [[File:A man pours Arabic coffee.ogg|thumb|An Arab man pours traditional cup of Arabic coffee in Levant]] Arabic coffee is usually served just a few [[Litre|centiliters]] at a time. The waiter/host serves the guest just enough to cover the bottom of the cup. Usually, the coffee is boiling hot, so larger amounts would take too long to cool to a drinkable temperature. The guest drinks it and if he wishes, he will gesture to the waiter not to pour any more. Otherwise, the host/waiter will continue to serve another few centilitres at a time until the guest indicates he has had enough. The most common practice is to drink only one cup since serving coffee serves as a ceremonial act of kindness and hospitality. Sometimes people also drink larger volumes during conversations.{{cite web|url=http://gwnunn.com/blog/2011/03/arabic-coffee-service/|title=Arabic Coffee Service {{!}} GWNunn.com|website=gwnunn.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-14}} == Customs == The cups are normally only filled partway, and the custom is to drink three cups.{{Cite news|url=https://cabincrewexcellence.com/arabic-coffee-a-welcoming-ritual/|title=Arabic Coffee - A Welcoming Ritual|work=Cabin Crew Excellence|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}} Arabic coffee has a prominent place in traditional [[Arabs|Arab]] holidays and special events such as [[Ramadan]] and [[Muslim holidays|Eid]]. === Fortune-telling === Arabic coffee reading ({{Lang-ar|قراءة الفنجان|qirāʾat al-finjān|}}), is similar to tea-leaf reading; the client is asked to consume strong fresh Arabic coffee leaving approximately a teaspoon of liquid in the cup. The cup is then inverted onto a saucer to allowing the residual liquid to drain away. The reader will then interpret the patterns formed by the thick residue on the inside of the cup.{{cite web|title=Jane - Fortune Teller {{!}} Middlesex{{!}} South East{{!}} UK - Contraband Events|url=https://www.contrabandevents.com/project/jane-fortune-teller-middlesex-south-east-uk/|website=Contraband Events}} === Funeral === In Arabic [[funeral]]s gather families and extended relatives, who drink bitter and unsweetened coffee and restore the life and characteristics of the deceased., the men and women gather separately, it has become very fashionable to employ very presentable women whose only job is to serve coffee all day to the women. Male waiters serve the men. [[Arab Muslims]] and [[Arab Christians|Christians]] share this tradition.{{cite web|url=https://imeu.org/article/social-customs-and-traditions|title=Palestinian Social Customs and Traditions {{!}} IMEU|last=IMEU|website=imeu.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-14}} == Nutrition facts == A small cup of Arabic coffee has almost no calories or fat. It contains a small amount of protein.{{Cite news|url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/296924-arabic-coffee-nutrition-information/|title=Arabic Coffee Nutrition Information|last=Cherney|first=Kristeen|work=LIVESTRONG.COM|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://blog.raynatours.com/5-interesting-facts-arabic-coffee/|title=5 Interesting Facts About Arabic Coffee|last=Tulsani|first=Manoj|date=2013-05-29|work=Travel Tips and Experience - Rayna Tours and Travels|access-date=2017-04-14|language=en-US}} ==See also== *[[Arabic tea]] *[[Arab cuisine]] *[[Home roasting coffee]] *[[Green coffee]] *[[Turkish coffee]] {{portal bar|Arab world|Middle East|Coffee}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} * {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-7wnpIi3VRwC&pg=PA37 | title=Middle Eastern Kitchen | publisher=Hippocrene Books | author=Basan, Ghillie | year=2007 | page=37 | isbn=0781811902}} * {{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0QxRp3jlQlsC&pg=PA44 | title=Coffee Love: 50 Ways to Drink Your Java | publisher=John Wiley & Sons | author=Young, Daniel | year=2009 | page=44 | isbn=0470289376}} {{Coffee|nocat=1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arabic Coffee}} [[Category:Arab cuisine]] [[Category:Arabic drinks]] [[Category:Arab culture]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian cuisine]] [[Category:Yemeni cuisine]] [[Category:Omani cuisine]] [[Category:Levantine cuisine]] [[Category:Palestinian cuisine]] [[Category:Lebanese cuisine]] [[Category:Syrian cuisine]] [[Category:Jordanian cuisine]] [[Category:Iraqi cuisine]] [[Category:Qatari cuisine]] [[Category:Coffee preparation]] [[Category:Arab inventions]]

{{one source|date=October 2010}}
The '''Association of Health Care Journalists''' is an independent, [[nonprofit organization]] dedicated to advancing public understanding of [[health care]] issues. Its mission is to improve the quality, accuracy and visibility of [[Health care journalism|health care reporting, writing and editing]]. There are more than 1,500 members of AHCJ. The Association is based in [[Columbia, Missouri]], at the [[Missouri School of Journalism]].
==History== The Association incorporated in 1998 and procured [[501(c)3]] status in 1999. In 2004 (at the fifth national conference in [[Minneapolis]]), the membership approved conversion of the Association to a [[501(c)6]] trade association with a supporting 501(c)3 charitable organization - the Center for Excellence in Health Care Journalism. The association holds annual [[meetings]], publishes [[newsletters]], operates a [[website]] and advocates on behalf of health [[journalists]] and the free flow of information. The Center presents training events, publishes educational materials and undertakes other educational projects aimed at improving the state of health [[journalism]].
==Resources== AHCJ and the Center offer a number of resources and services intended to help journalists do in-depth and accurate reporting on health and health care issues. Its initiatives include the Awards for Excellence in Health Care Journalism,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/awards-entryFormRules.php |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | Awards-Entry Form and Rules |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101031105046/http://healthjournalism.org/awards-entryFormRules.php| archivedate= 31 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> an active Web site and blog, annual conferences,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=1 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | Training Conferences |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025011554/http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=1| archivedate= 25 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> smaller training events,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=2 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | Training Workshops |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025011601/http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=2| archivedate= 25 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> online training,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=4 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | Training Online |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025005812/http://www.healthjournalism.org/calendar.php?EventType=1&EventSubType=4| archivedate= 25 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and fellowships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=60 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | About-News |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date=2008-11-10 |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101117135622/http://healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=60| archivedate= 17 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Awards== The Awards for Excellence in Health Care Journalism are notable as the only awards program for health journalism that is not influenced or funded by commercial or special-interest groups, an issue that has received scrutiny recently.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/22/health/22journalists.html?ref=health | work=The New York Times | title=Conflicts of Interest May Ensnare Journalists, Too | date=2008-11-22}}</ref>
The Association advocates for high [[ethical standards]] in health care reporting and has taken a position against news organizations entering into arrangements with hospitals that improperly influence health coverage,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=59 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | About-News |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date=2008-08-11 |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101117135800/http://healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=59| archivedate= 17 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> urged reporters to resist signing [[confidentiality agreements]] with hospitals<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=51 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | About-News |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101117210125/http://healthjournalism.org//about-news-detail.php?id=51| archivedate= 17 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and opposed secrecy clauses in [[contracts]] between medical device manufacturers and hospitals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=28 |title=Association of Health Care Journalists | About-News |publisher=Healthjournalism.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101117135319/http://healthjournalism.org/about-news-detail.php?id=28| archivedate= 17 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.healthjournalism.org}} *[http://www.healthjournalism.org/blog Blog]
[[Category:Medical journalism]]

revision.text:
[[File:Bras d'honneur.jpg|thumb|Bras d'honneur]] A '''''bras d'honneur''''' ({{IPA-fr|bʁa dɔˈnœʁ}} "arm of honor"), '''Iberian slap''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''corte de manga''), or '''Italian salute'''<ref>Hughes, Geoffrey (2015). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=sIGsBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA259&lpg=PA259&dq="italian+salute" An Encyclopedia of Swearing: The Social History of Oaths, Profanity, Foul Language, and Ethnic Slurs in the English-speaking World]''. [[Routledge]]. p. 259</ref> is an [[obscene gesture]] most common in [[Romance-speaking Europe|Romanic Europe]] ([[Italy]], [[France]], [[Portugal]], [[Spain]]), [[Latin America]], [[Russia]], [[Poland]], [[Croatia]], [[Turkey]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Ireland]] and in parts of [[Scotland]]. To make the gesture, an arm is bent in an L-shape, with the fist pointing upwards; the other hand then grips the biceps of the bent arm as it is emphatically raised to a vertical position. It has the same meaning as giving [[the finger]] (known as ''le doigt d'honneur'').
== International nomenclature == {{Refimprove section|date=April 2011}} * In [[Italy]], the gesture is often referred to as ''gesto dell'ombrello'', meaning literally "[[umbrella]] gesture." Its most famous occurrence in [[Italian cinema]] is in [[Federico Fellini]]'s ''[[I vitelloni]]'' (1953), where the idler played by [[Alberto Sordi]] jeers at a group of workmen, combining this gesture with a [[Blowing a raspberry|raspberry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jD45TQIfcoo |title=Fellini – I vitelloni |publisher=YouTube}}</ref> * In [[Brazil]], the gesture is known as a "[[banana]]" and carries the same connotation as giving someone [[the finger]]. It can also be used to denote disrespectfully ignoring what someone just said, analogous in meaning to the American expression, "I don't give a fuck."<ref name=cascudo>[https://books.google.com.br/books?id=-69cBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT336&lpg=PT336&dq=banana+gesto&source=bl&ots=hXWoOIJmW8&sig=N5TT3yfy03pPdaLw_AR783bfyRg&hl=pt-BR&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJmvzlxu7OAhUEk5AKHR7sAxI4FBDoAQglMAI#v=onepage&q=banana%20gesto&f=false História de nossos gestos]</ref> * [[Portugal]] has a similar term, "''[[wikt:manguito#Portuguese|manguito]]''". It is also the most characteristic gesture performed by the Portuguese [[everyman]] "[[Zé Povinho]]". <ref name=cascudo/> * In most Spanish-speaking countries, the gesture is known as ''"corte de manga(s)"'' ("sleeve-cut"), with the same insulting meaning. * In [[Catalonia]] the gesture is called a "botifarra", the name of a local [[botifarra|sausage]] speciality. * In [[Colombia]] the gesture has the function of replacing the raised middle finger, meaning "''jódete''" or "''friégate''". * In [[Mexico]], the gesture is known as a "''mentada de madre''", an insult directed towards the mother of the offended (commonly accompanied by the phrase "chinga tu madre", "fuck your mother"), though it is done with a single hand. * In [[Poland]], the gesture is known as ''wał'' or ''gest Kozakiewicza'' ("[[Kozakiewicz's gesture]]") after [[Władysław Kozakiewicz]], who famously displayed this gesture after winning the gold medal in the [[pole vault]] at the [[Athletics at the 1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Summer Olympics]] in front of a hostile crowd in [[Moscow]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mn0in1fzqoI& |title=gest Kozakiewicza Moskwa 1980 |publisher=YouTube}}</ref> This coincided with the rise of the Solidarity Union in Poland in 1980. * In [[Croatia]], the gesture is known as ''bosanski grb'' ("The Bosnian Coat-of-Arms") after the [[Coat of arms of Bosnia and Herzegovina#Historic arms|territorial coat of arms]] of [[Bosnia]] during the Austro-Hungarian reign, that is somewhat similar to the actual gesture. * In [[Bulgaria]] the bent hand is sometimes used to form a [[facepalm]] when performing this gesture, expressing strong disappointment or mocking a failure. * In [[Turkey]] the gesture is called a "kol" which just literally means arm. It has an insulting meaning. * In the [[United States]], the gesture is known as "The Arm" or as the "Italian salute." * In [[Malta]], this implies a maternal insult: "fuck your mother".
==In popular culture== {{In popular culture|section|date=October 2017}} * In the comedy film ''[[Monty Python's Life of Brian]]'', an old man is supposed to fight a professional gladiator, but instead keeps running around the arena. The gladiator dies of a heart disease and the old man keeps running, makes victorious gestures, then kneels and gives the local Roman authorities the ''bras d'honneur''. * In the musical ''[[West Side Story]]'', performances of the song "Gee, Officer Krupke" end with the entire Jets gang giving the audience the ''bras d'honneur'' while singing the final line. *In the musical ’’[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]’’ during “La Vie Boheme” the ‘’ bras d’honneur’’ is made after singing the line: “Why Dorthoy and Toto went over the rainbow, to blow off Auntie Em!” * In the film adaptation of the musical ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'', Rizzo makes this gesture towards Vince Fontaine after being eliminated from the dance contest. * In the movie ''[[Poltergeist (1982 film)|Poltergeist]]'', Dana Freeling makes a big show of giving a ''bras d'honneur'' with a raised middle finger to a group of workmen. * In the movie ''[[Spaceballs]]'', the Spaceballs' salute involves giving the ''bras d'honneur'' and then opening the fist to wave at the salutee. * In the movie ''[[Midnight Cowboy]]'', the character Enrico Salvatore (played by Dustin Hoffman) gives a taxi driver the gesture during the famous "I'm walking here!" scene while crossing the road. * In the film ''[[Major League (film)|Major League]]'', the team gives a synchronized ''bras d'honneur'' to Rachael Phelps behind her back in the locker room after she calls them pansies. The gesture is then transitioned into a cross arm to hide it when she turns around. * In the [[James Bond movie]] ''[[GoldenEye]]'', Irina ([[Minnie Driver]]), the woman who is singing ''Stand By Your Man'' rather badly, makes this gesture to [[Valentin Dmitrovich Zukovsky]] ([[Robbie Coltrane]]) when he tells her to "take a hike", after Bond ([[Pierce Brosnan]]) remarks, "Who's strangling the cat?" * In the Christmas comedy ''[[Jingle All the Way]]'', Myron ([[Sinbad (comedian)|Sinbad]]) - having dressed up as a villainous character at a Christmas parade - gives the gesture to some of the booing audience and tells them to "Shut up!", causing one of the TV commentators to question if that was a part of the script. * The cover of the [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]] album ''[[Too Old to Rock 'n' Roll: Too Young to Die!]]'' depicts the gesture. *In the film ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'', Matt Hooper gives Quint the ''bras d'honneur'' after he tells Hooper, "Well it proves one thing Mr. Hooper. It proves that you wealthy college boys don't have the education enough to admit when you're wrong." * In the comedy film ''[[DodgeBall: A True Underdog Story]]'', Derek (a mean person who is a part of the cheerleading squad with Amber) performs the gesture to Justin due to the latter's infatuation with Amber. *In the film ''[[Mean Girls]]'', when Cady Heron waves at Janis Ian, Janis responds by waving back which then turns into a bras d'honneur. *During the song "Good Night and Thank You" in the musical ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]'', the narrator [[Che Guevara|Che]] dismisses each of [[Eva Peron|Eva's]] early lovers by singing, "Which means…." and making the ''bras d'honneur'' gesture. *In ''[[Mario Kart 8#Mario Kart 8 Deluxe|Mario Kart 8 Deluxe]]'', an updated version of ''[[Mario Kart 8]]'' for the [[Nintendo Switch]], the Inkling Girl character from ''[[Splatoon]]''—one of the characters new to ''Mario Kart 8 Deluxe''—made this gesture when taunting nearby opponents that have been successfully hit with items. On May 17, 2017, this was removed and replaced with a simple fist pump in the version 1.1 update, when Nintendo discovered that the ''bras d'honneur'' was an obscene gesture in parts of Europe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kotaku.com/mario-kart-update-removes-offensive-gesture-1795318877|title=Mario Kart Update Removes Offensive Gesture|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=2017-05-17|work=Kotaku|access-date=2017-09-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> *In the video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]'', Ryder gives the ''bras d'honneur'' just before his death. *In the video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'', Franklin gives Trevor the ''bras d'honneur'' after a brief argument with Denise. *In the action-adventure stealth game ''[[Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater]]'', Eva performs, what appears to be, this gesture to Colonel Volgin in the cutscene leading up to the final phase of the battle against the Shagohod. *Despite the character being American, Jean-Claude Van Damme delivers a bras d'honneur to Bison in [[Street Fighter (1994 film)]]. *In the 1981 film ''[[Mad Max 2|Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior]]'', The Gyro Captain ([[Bruce Spence]]) performs this gesture after dropping a fire bomb during the films climactic chase scene. *In the Japanese version of the video game ''[[Super Mario RPG]]'', the character [[Bowser (character)|Bowser]] can be seen making the gesture as his victory animation. This animation was removed from the western release possibly because it was deemed too offensive. *In the BBC television series ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' Arnold Rimmer gives the ''bras d'honneur'' multiple times throughout the series, most notably in the episode "Me²".
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://french.about.com/library/weekly/aa020901u.htm French gestures on About.com]
{{Gestures}}
[[Category:Hand gestures]] [[Category:Obscenity]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Caravan | image = "Caravan"_(1946_film).jpg | image_size = | caption = Detail from Italian poster | director = [[Arthur Crabtree]] | producer = [[Harold Huth]] | writer = [[Roland Pertwee]] (writer)
[[Eleanor Smith (writer)|Eleanor Smith]]
(original novel) | starring = [[Stewart Granger]]
[[Jean Kent]]
[[Anne Crawford]]
[[Dennis Price]]
[[Robert Helpmann]]
[[Gerard Heinz]] | music = [[Bretton Byrd]] (uncredited) | cinematography = [[Stephen Dade]]
[[Cyril J. Knowles]] (location photography) | editing = Charles Knott | distributor = [[General Film Distributors]] (UK) | released = 3 June 1946 | runtime = 80 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = 649,800 admissions (France)[http://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/&prev=search Box office information for Stewart Granger films in France] at Box Office Story }} '''''Caravan''''' is a 1946 British black-and-white [[drama film]] directed by [[Arthur Crabtree]]. It was one of the [[Gainsborough melodramas]] and is based on a novel ''[[Caravan (novel)|Caravan]]'' by [[Eleanor Smith (writer)|Eleanor Smith]]. ==Plot== In late 19th-century London, destitute Richard Darrell ([[Stewart Granger]]) rescues Don Carlos ([[Gerard Heinz]]) from two robbers. When Richard returns for the manuscript he inadvertently left behind, he is encouraged by Don Carlos to talk about his background. The son of a poor country doctor, he met the upper class Oriana Camperdene and Francis Castleton during their childhood; he and Francis became rivals for Oriana's affections. Oriana and her father left for Spain, but the couple were reunited as adults and agreed to marry, much to Francis's disgust. However, they postponed the wedding for a year so that Richard could go to London and make his fortune as a writer. However, though he has completed a novel, no one wants to publish it and his year is almost up. Don Carlos offers to publish it and asks him to take a valuable [[necklace]], which once belonged to Queen Isabella of Castile, to [[Granada]]. Bidding farewell to Oriana ([[Anne Crawford]]), Richard sets out. On the way, he meets Wycroft ([[Robert Helpmann]]), who assaults, robs and nearly kills Richard on behalf of his dastardly master, Sir Francis Castleton ([[Dennis Price]]). Oriana thinks Richard is dead and, with her father recently dead, marries Francis, whilst Richard loses his memory as a result of the assault and marries a [[Romani people|gypsy]] girl named Rosal ([[Jean Kent]]). However, everyone meets again... ==Cast== *[[Stewart Granger]] as Richard *[[Jean Kent]] as Rosal *[[Anne Crawford]] as Oriana *[[Dennis Price]] as Francis *[[Robert Helpmann]] as Wycroft *[[Gerard Heinz]] as Don Carlos *[[Enid Stamp Taylor]] as Bertha *[[David Horne (actor)|David Horne]] as Camperdene *[[John Salew]] as Diego *[[Arthur Goullet]] as Suiza *Julian Somers as Manoel *Peter Murray as Juan *[[Xavier Petulengro|Gypsy Petulengro]] as Paco *Sylvie St. Clair as Marie *Henry Morrell as Cumbermere *Victoria Campbell as Fanny *[[Mabel Constanduros]] as Woman *Josef Ramart as Jose *Erin de Selfa as Singer in Cafe *Philip Guard as Young Francis *Peter Mullins as Young Richard *[[Jacqueline Boyer]] as Young Oriana ==Production== The film was meant to follow ''[[The Magic Bow]]'', but that was postponed due to the illness of [[Phyllis Calvert]] so, ''Caravan'' had to be rushed into production.{{cite news|title=BUSY BRITONS: Two Down and One to Go|author=C.A. LEJEUNE|work=New York Times|date=24 June 1945|page=27}} Location filming took place in North Wales.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article230454547 |title=Menuhin music in British film |newspaper=[[The Sun (Sydney)|The Sun]] |issue=2201 |location=Sydney |date=17 June 1945 |accessdate=27 October 2017 |page=3 (SUPPLEMENT TO THE SUNDAY SUN WEEK END MAGAZINE) |via=National Library of Australia}} Jean Kent met her future husband during the making of the movie.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59351468 |title=FILM CABLE FROM LONDON:. |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Perth |date=17 March 1946 |accessdate=2 February 2014 |page=13 Supplement: The Sunday Times MAGAZINE |via=National Library of Australia}} ==Release== The film was one of the most popular British releases of 1946.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59472238 |title=Britain's Best Films. |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Perth |date=16 February 1947 |accessdate=2 February 2014 |page=12 Supplement: SUPPLEMENT TO THE SUNDAY TIMES |via=National Library of Australia}} According to trade papers, the film was a "notable box office attraction" at British cinemas.[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=xtGIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209&dq=hungry+hill+film+box+office&source=bl&ots=MTsQXadYDw&sig=2h-5aG3Vy4tT_h1mlC4mfRi18JQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ8b6P1YHMAhVEFqYKHcy9BF8Q6AEIMzAF#v=onepage&q=hungry%20hill%20film%20box%20office&f=false Robert Murphy, ''Realism and Tinsel: Cinema and Society in Britain 1939-48'' 2003 p209] It was the most successful film at the British box office in 1946 after ''[[The Wicked Lady]]'', ''[[The Bells of St Marys]]'', ''[[Piccadilly Incident]]'', ''[[The Captive Heart]]'' and ''[[The Road to Utopia]]''.{{cite news|title=Hollywood Sneaks In 15 Films on '25 Best' List of Arty Britain|newspaper=The Washington Post |date=15 Jan 1947|page= 2}} Stewart Granger later called the movie "terrible".Brian MacFarlane, ''An Autobiography of British Cinema'', Methuen 1997 p 230 ==Critical reception== ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, "Granger and the rest of the cast alternate between grappling with stilted lines and an embarrassingly archaic situation with neither the players nor plot making much entertainment, while 'Caravan' moves with the speed of an oxcart."{{cite web|author=A.. W. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B03E0D6133CE23BBC4951DFB2668382659EDE&module=Search&mabReward=relbias%3Ar |title=Movie Review – Caravan – Meredith Documentary, 'A Yank Comes Back,' at Symphony – 'Caravan' at Beacon |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=1949-04-21 |accessdate=2014-07-24}} ''[[TV Guide]]'' noted "strong direction, brilliant individual performances, and production values far above the usual run of British films work beautifully together as one melodramatic situation is piled on another." {{cite web|url=http://movies.tvguide.com/caravan/review/110335 |title=Caravan Review |publisher=Movies.tvguide.com |date=2012-11-28 |accessdate=2014-07-24}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0037578|Caravan}} * {{Amg movie|86671|Caravan}} *[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/440361/index.html ''Caravan''] at [[BFI Screenonline]] *[https://archive.org/stream/variety162-1946-04#page/n166/mode/1up Review of film] at ''Variety'' {{Arthur Crabtree}} {{Gainsborough Pictures}} [[Category:1946 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British black-and-white films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about amnesia]] [[Category:Films based on British novels]] [[Category:Films based on romance novels]] [[Category:Films directed by Arthur Crabtree]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Films set in Spain]] [[Category:Films set in the 19th century]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]] [[Category:Gainsborough Pictures films]] [[Category:Melodramas]]

{{italic title}} '''''Comrades and Strangers''''' is the memoir of [[Michael Harrold]], the first British person to reside in [[North Korea]]. The book was written to demystify North Korean society.<ref>{{cite news |title=Comrades and Strangers: Behind the Closed Doors of North Korea |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-4406708/Comrades-and-Strangers-Behind-the.html |work=[[New Internationalist]] |date=1 June 2005 |accessdate=2008-12-12 }}</ref>
==History== Harrold, who sought a year or two of adventure after graduating from university, flew to [[Pyongyang]], [[North Korea]], in the spring of 1987 after accepting employment in the country’s Foreign Languages Publishing House, where he assisted in the translation of President [[Kim Il Sung]]’s words into English.<ref>{{cite news |title=Book review: A glimpse behind the last Iron Curtain |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/731651/Book-review-A-glimpse-behind-the-last-Iron-Curtain.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=12 November 2004 |accessdate=2008-12-12 | location=London | first=Robert | last=Willoughby}}</ref> In the book, Harrold intertwines his personal experiences living and working in the country with the recent history of Korea.
In the early days, Harrold enjoyed his important status and the accompanying trappings of his work in [[North Korea]]. In addition to revising the words of President [[Kim Il Sung]], he was given a prominent position at ceremonial events. Moreover, he was relatively well-paid. This relatively high salary allowed for a social life that was closed to all but the other foreigners in [[Pyongyang]] and a small North Korean elite. Although his interaction with North Koreans was severely restricted, he did become acquainted with some of Pyongyang’s better off.
Harrold spent nearly seven years in [[North Korea]], during which time he had many unusual experiences that make fascinating reading. He also developed a relatively unique understanding of North Korean society.
Eventually, circumstances led to Harrold's being forced to leave the country. As a result, he was left with a deep sense of resentment toward [[North Korea]]. Looking back on his experiences, Harrold admits his earlier naïveté, when he believed that “international problems could best be resolved by ordinary people over a pint or two of beer (403).” In the end, he was critical of [[North Korea]]; nevertheless, he refused to blame the North Korean leadership for all the problems facing the country today, arguing that international actors, namely the United States, share the responsibility.
*''Comrades and Strangers: Behind the Closed Doors of North Korea'' John Wiley and Sons, 2004, {{ISBN|978-0-470-86976-5}}
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:Books about North Korea]] [[Category:North Korean society]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox country demographics | country = {{ISR}} | image = [[File:Population of Israel since 1949.svg|270px]] | caption = Population of [[Israel]] since 1949
<!-- main demographics --> | size_of_population = 8,855,000 ([[List of countries by population|96th]]) <ref>http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/newhodaot/hodaa_template.html?hodaa=201711387</ref> | density = 401/km<sup>2</sup> ([[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density|35th]]) | growth = 2.0% <ref name="CBS_Growth_Rate">{{cite web |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/www/publications13/yarhon0413/pdf/b1.pdf |title=Growth Rate. Yearly average since last census conducted 27/12/2008. }}</ref> | birth = 21.5 births/1,000 population ([[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by birth rate|101st]]) | death = 5.2 deaths/1,000 population ([[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by death rate|174th]]) | life = 82.01 years ([[List of countries by life expectancy|8th]]) | life_male = 80.02 years | life_female = 84.0 years | fertility = 3.13 children born/woman ([[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate|76th]]) | infant_mortality = 4.03 deaths/1,000 live births ([[List of countries by infant mortality rate|25th]])
<!-- age structure --> | age_0-14_years = 27.3% | age_15-64_years = 62.2% | age_65_years = 10.5%
<!-- sex ratio --> | total_mf_ratio = 1.01 male(s)/female | sr_at_birth = 1.05 male(s)/female | sr_under_15 = 1.05 male(s)/female | sr_15-64_years = 1.03 male(s)/female | sr_65_years_over = 0.78 male(s)/female
<!-- nationality --> | nation = [[Israelis]] | major_ethnic = [[Israeli Jews|Jews]] | minor_ethnic = [[Arab citizens of Israel|Arabs]], [[Israeli Druze|Druze]], [[Arameans in Israel|Arameans]], [[Armenians in Israel|Armenians]], [[Circassians in Israel|Circassians]]
<!-- language --> | official = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | spoken = [[Arabic]], [[Russian language in Israel|Russian]], [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]], [[French language|French]], [[English language|English]] }}
The '''demographics of Israel''' are monitored by the [[Israel Central Bureau of Statistics]]. The [[State of Israel]] has a population of approximately 8,855,000 inhabitants as of the first half of 2018.<ref name="CBSPopulation2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/newhodaot/hodaa_template.html?hodaa=201711387|title=Population of Israel on the Eve of 2018 - 8.8 Million|last=|first=|date=31 December 2017|website=|work=Press Release|publisher=Israel Central Bureau of Statistics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> Some 74.5% are [[Israeli Jews|Jews]] of all backgrounds (about 6,556,000 individuals), 20.9% are [[Arab citizens of Israel|Arab]] of any religion other than [[Judaism|Jewish]] (about 1,837,000 individuals), while the remaining 4.6% (about 400,000 individuals) are defined as "others", including persons of Jewish ancestry deemed non-Jewish by religious law and persons of non-Jewish ancestry who are family members of Jewish immigrants (neither of which are registered at the [[Ministry of Interior (Israel)|Ministry of Interior]] as Jews), [[Christian]] non-Arabs, [[Mawali|Muslim non-Arabs]] and all other residents who have neither an ethnic nor religious classification.
Israel's annual population growth rate stood at 2.0% in 2015, more than three times faster than the [[OECD]] average of around 0.6%.<ref name="OECD_Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://stats.oecd.org/|title=Population growth, OECD |year=2012 |publisher=OECD |accessdate=17 Feb 2014}}</ref> With an average of three children per woman, Israel also has the highest [[fertility rate]] in the OECD by a considerable margin and much higher than the OECD average of 1.7.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oecd.org/israel/OECD-SocietyAtaGlance2014-Highlights-Israel.pdf|title=Society at a Glance 2014 Highlights: ISRAEL, OECD |year=2014 |publisher=OECD |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
Generally, population trends in Israel reflect distinct patterns of two sub-groups: Jews (around 74.71% of the population) and Arabs (20.7%).<ref>http://www.cbs.gov.il/publications/tec27.pdf</ref> Over the past decade, the [[Islam|Muslim]] annual population growth has fallen significantly, from around 3% to less than 2.2% by 2013,<ref>[http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/shnaton/templ_shnaton_e.html?num_tab=st02_01&CYear=2013 Statistical Abstract of Israel 2013 - No. 64 Subject 2 - Table No. 1<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> while the overall Jewish growth rate rose from around 1.4% to 1.7%, primarily due to the expanding [[Orthodox Jewish]] sector.<ref>https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/completingfertility/RevisedFriedlanderpaper.PDF</ref>
==Definition== The territory of Israel can be defined in a number of ways as a result of a complex and unresolved political situation (see table below). For example, whilst the [[Israel Central Bureau of Statistics]] defines the area of Israel to include the [[annexed]] [[East Jerusalem]] and [[Golan Heights]], and to exclude the militarily controlled regions of the [[West Bank]], the CBS defines the population of Israel to also include [[Israeli settlers]] living in the Area C of West Bank and the Muslim residents of East Jerusalem and Area C, who have Israeli residency or citizenship.

==Cities== {{Main article|List of Israeli cities}} Within [[Local government in Israel|Israel's system of local government]], an urban municipality can be granted a [[City council (Israel)|city council]] by the [[Israeli Ministry of Interior|Israeli Interior Ministry]] when its population exceeds 20,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Branches%20of%20Government/Executive/Israeli%20Democracy%20-%20How%20does%20it%20work#local |title=Structure of Local Government |accessdate=2008-04-11 |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs}}</ref> The term "city" does not generally refer to [[Local council (Israel)|local councils]] or [[urban agglomeration]]s, even though a defined city often contains only a small portion of an [[urban area]] or [[metropolitan area]]'s population. {{Largest cities of Israel}}
==Ethnic and religious groups== {{Further information|Israelis}} The most prominent [[Ethnic group|ethnic]] and [[Religious denomination|religious groups]], who live in Israel at present and who are Israeli citizens or nationals, are as follows:
===Jews=== {{Main article|Israeli Jews}} According to [[Israel Central Bureau of Statistics|Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics]], in 2008, of Israel's 7.3 million people, 75.6 percent were Jews of any background.<ref name="CBS_month_pop">{{cite web|url=http://www1.cbs.gov.il/publications13/yarhon0413/pdf/b1.pdf |title=Population, by Population Group |date=31 December 2013 |work=Monthly Bulletin of Statistics |publisher=Israel Central Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=17 Feb 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203172044/http://www1.cbs.gov.il/publications13/yarhon0413/pdf/b1.pdf |archivedate=3 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> Among them, 70.3 percent were [[Sabra (person)|Sabras]] (born in Israel), mostly second- or third-generation Israelis, and the rest are [[Aliyah|olim]] (Jewish immigrants to Israel)—20.5 percent from Europe and the Americas, and 9.2 percent from Asia and Africa, including the [[Arab world|Arab countries]].<ref name="CBS_2008_jews_origin">{{cite web |url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/shnaton/templ_shnaton_e.html?num_tab=st02_24x&CYear=2009 |title=Table 2.24 - Jews, by country of origin and age |accessdate=22 March 2010 |first=CBS |last=Statistical Abstract of Israel, 2009 |authorlink=Israel Central Bureau of Statistics |format=PDF}}</ref>
